texts.shortText: Small, mainly white gull with grey back and upper wings, outermost primaries black with white tips. Head and throat with pale grey ‘hood’ (darker and more prominent in breeding season) that is bounded by darker line along its lower edge. Eyes yellowish-white. Bill and legs bright red. Juveniles with head white, upper parts brown, bill black, legs pinkish.
Total length 42 cm, wingspan 102 cm mass about 280 g, sexes alike.

Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa, the supposed South American population probably representing a distinct species.

Local/Regional: Whole region, but relatively uncommon along west coast.

Found both along the coast and across the wetter parts of interior, where associated with lakes and dams, larger rivers, sewage pans, etc. Uncommon on west coast, where they may mix with flocks of Hartlaub’s gull. Usually live in small flocks. Spend the night in communal roosts, departing for feeding grounds in the morning and returning in the evening.

Opportunistic and feeds by day. In marine habitats may plunge dive, dip for small invertebrates while swimming, or catch prey by running though shallow water or on drift-line. Inland feed on aquatic invertebrates such as snails and insect larvae, on termite alates, moths around lights and the like. Also follows ploughs, scavenges at dumps, picnic sites or for offal and scraps.

Breeds in colonies of a few to several hundred pairs, especially on islands. Nest a shallow bowl of grass, twigs and leaves. Mostly breeds in winter, usually laying 3 eggs which are pale blue-green or brown with spotted and blotched with brown.

Can easily be confused with Hartlaub’s gull, which is the dominant species on the west coast, where Grey-headed gull is rare. Hartlaub’s gull is slightly smaller with shorter legs and bill and has a much less pronounced, lavender hood, dark brown to red legs and dark-brown eyes.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 443).
